fields.title: Postgres
fields.markdown_text:
#### Change a User's Password

    ALTER USER davide WITH PASSWORD 'hu8jmn3';
fields.html_text:
Change a User's Password

ALTER USER davide WITH PASSWORD 'hu8jmn3';

fields.title: Jenkins CI
fields.markdown_text:
#### To give Jenkins a new port edit the file at:

    /etc/default/jenkins

and add the port number you want to the `HTTP_PORT VARIABLE`:

    # port for HTTP connector (default 8080; disable with -1)
    HTTP_PORT=9090

Then you should restart Jenkins with `sudo service jenkins restart`.

#### Upgrade Jenkins
Once installed, you can upgrade to the later version of Jenkins by running:

    sudo apt-get update
    sudo apt-get install jenkins

#### Login to Jenkins box

    sudo su - jenkins

Switches you to Jenkins home directory `/var/lib/jenkins`
fields.html_text:
To give Jenkins a new port edit the file at:

/etc/default/jenkins

and add the port number you want to the HTTP_PORT VARIABLE:

# port for HTTP connector (default 8080; disable with -1)
HTTP_PORT=9090

Then you should restart Jenkins with sudo service jenkins restart.

Upgrade Jenkins

Once installed, you can upgrade to the later version of Jenkins by running:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install jenkins

Login to Jenkins box

sudo su - jenkins

Switches you to Jenkins home directory /var/lib/jenkins

fields.title: Git
fields.markdown_text:
#### Changing the default Git remote 'push to' default

To change which upstream remote is "wired" to your branch, use the git branch command with the upstream configuration flag. Ensure the remote exists first:

    git remote -v

Set the preferred remote for the current (checked out) branch:

    git branch --set-upstream-to <remote-name>

Validate the branch is setup with the correct upstream remote:

    git branch -vv

#### Difference between master branch and the current branch

    git diff master current_branch_name
fields.html_text:
Changing the default Git remote 'push to' default

To change which upstream remote is "wired" to your branch, use the git branch command with the upstream configuration flag. Ensure the remote exists first:

git remote -v

Set the preferred remote for the current (checked out) branch:

git branch --set-upstream-to <remote-name>

Validate the branch is setup with the correct upstream remote:

git branch -vv

Difference between master branch and the current branch

git diff master current_branch_name

fields.title: MySQL
fields.markdown_text: #### Install MySQL First update your system: sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get upgrade Next install MySQL: sudo apt-get install mysql-server During the installation process, you will be prompted to set a password for the MySQL root user as shown below. Choose a strong password and keep it in a safe place for future reference. MySQL will bind to localhost (127.0.0.1) by default. Run the mysql_secure_installation script to address several security concerns in a default MySQL installation. sudo mysql_secure_installation You will be given the choice to change the MySQL root password, remove anonymous user accounts, disable root logins outside of localhost, and remove test databases. It is recommended that you answer yes to these options. You can read more about the script in in the [MySQL Reference Manual](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.5/en/mysql-secure-installation.html). #### Login to MySQL To log in to MySQL as the root user: mysql -u root -p When prompted, enter the root password you assigned when the mysql_secure_installation script was run. You’ll then be presented with the MySQL monitor prompt: #### Create a Database and a Database User In the example below, `myprojectdb` is the name of the database, `myprojectuser` is the user, and `password` is the user’s password. CREATE DATABASE myprojectdb; CREATE USER myprojectuser@localhost IDENTIFIED BY 'password'; Give our database user, access rights to the database created: GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON myprojectdb.* TO myprojectuser@localhost; Flush the changes so that they will be available during the current session: FLUSH PRIVILEGES; Exit the SQL prompt to get back to your regular shell session: exit #### Re-Install MySQL First remove MySQL: sudo apt-get remove --purge mysql-server mysql-client mysql-common sudo apt-get autoremove sudo apt-get autoclean Then re-install: sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get install mysql-server sudo mysql_install_db sudo /usr/bin/mysql_secure_installation #### Update database user name UPDATE mysql.user SET user='newusername' WHERE user='root'; FLUSH PRIVILEGES; #### Display all users that can access database 'X' Connect to the MySQL instance as a root/admin user and enter the following command: SELECT user FROM mysql.db WHERE db='database_name'; #### Display the structure of a table If you If you want to find out about the structure of a table, the `DESCRIBE` statement is useful; it displays information about each of a table's columns: DESCRIBE tablename; For more information see [here](http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/getting-information.html) #### Get database table sizes Here is a super simple SQL query to determine the size of all tables in a given database: SELECT TABLE_NAME as `TABLE`, round(((data_length + index_length) / 1024 / 1024), 2) `Size in MB` FROM information_schema.TABLES WHERE table_schema = "my_database_name" AND table_name = "my_table_name";
fields.html_text:
Install MySQL

First update your system:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get upgrade

Next install MySQL:

 sudo apt-get install mysql-server

During the installation process, you will be prompted to set a password for the MySQL root user as shown below. Choose a strong password and keep it in a safe place for future reference.

MySQL will bind to localhost (127.0.0.1) by default.

Run the mysql_secure_installation script to address several security concerns in a default MySQL installation.

sudo mysql_secure_installation

You will be given the choice to change the MySQL root password, remove anonymous user accounts, disable root logins outside of localhost, and remove test databases. It is recommended that you answer yes to these options. You can read more about the script in in the MySQL Reference Manual.

Login to MySQL

To log in to MySQL as the root user:

mysql -u root -p

When prompted, enter the root password you assigned when the mysql_secure_installation script was run.

You’ll then be presented with the MySQL monitor prompt:

Create a Database and a Database User

In the example below, myprojectdb is the name of the database, myprojectuser is the user, and password is the user’s password.

CREATE DATABASE myprojectdb;
CREATE USER myprojectuser@localhost IDENTIFIED BY 'password';

Give our database user, access rights to the database created:

GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON myprojectdb.* TO myprojectuser@localhost;

Flush the changes so that they will be available during the current session:

FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

Exit the SQL prompt to get back to your regular shell session:

exit

Re-Install MySQL

First remove MySQL:

sudo apt-get remove --purge mysql-server mysql-client mysql-common
sudo apt-get autoremove
sudo apt-get autoclean

Then re-install:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install mysql-server
sudo mysql_install_db
sudo /usr/bin/mysql_secure_installation

Update database user name

UPDATE mysql.user SET user='newusername' WHERE user='root';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

Display all users that can access database 'X'

Connect to the MySQL instance as a root/admin user and enter the following command:

SELECT user FROM mysql.db WHERE db='database_name';

Display the structure of a table

If you If you want to find out about the structure of a table, the DESCRIBE statement is useful; it displays information about each of a table's columns:

DESCRIBE tablename;

For more information see here

Get database table sizes

Here is a super simple SQL query to determine the size of all tables in a given database:

SELECT TABLE_NAME as `TABLE`, round(((data_length + index_length) / 1024 / 1024), 2) `Size in MB` 
FROM information_schema.TABLES 
WHERE table_schema = "my_database_name" 
AND table_name = "my_table_name";

fields.title: Python
fields.markdown_text:
#### Get the first and last day of the month function

    import datetime

    # requires python-dateutil (http://labix.org/python-dateutil)
    from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta

    def get_month_day_range(date):
        """
        For a date 'date' returns the start and end date for the month of 'date'.
        Month with 31 days:
        >>> date = datetime.date(2011, 7, 27)
        >>> get_month_day_range(date)
        (datetime.date(2011, 7, 1), datetime.date(2011, 7, 31))
        Month with 28 days:
        >>> date = datetime.date(2011, 2, 15)
        >>> get_month_day_range(date)
        (datetime.date(2011, 2, 1), datetime.date(2011, 2, 28))
        """
        last_day = date + relativedelta(day=1, months=+1, days=-1)
        first_day = date + relativedelta(day=1)
        return first_day, last_day

    if __name__ == "__main__":
        import doctest
        doctest.testmod()

See original [here](https://gist.github.com/waynemoore/1109153)
fields.html_text:
Get the first and last day of the month function

import datetime

# requires python-dateutil (http://labix.org/python-dateutil)
from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta

def get_month_day_range(date):
    """
    For a date 'date' returns the start and end date for the month of 'date'.
    Month with 31 days:
    >>> date = datetime.date(2011, 7, 27)
    >>> get_month_day_range(date)
    (datetime.date(2011, 7, 1), datetime.date(2011, 7, 31))
    Month with 28 days:
    >>> date = datetime.date(2011, 2, 15)
    >>> get_month_day_range(date)
    (datetime.date(2011, 2, 1), datetime.date(2011, 2, 28))
    """
    last_day = date + relativedelta(day=1, months=+1, days=-1)
    first_day = date + relativedelta(day=1)
    return first_day, last_day

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import doctest
    doctest.testmod()

See original here

fields.title: Ubuntu
fields.markdown_text:
#### How to disable overlay scrollbars

Install Ubuntu tweak from Ubuntu Software Center, click on Scrolling and select Legacy other than Overlay.
fields.html_text:
How to disable overlay scrollbars

Install Ubuntu tweak from Ubuntu Software Center, click on Scrolling and select Legacy other than Overlay.
